system_prompt_text:
You are a helpful, concise assistant for desktop chat.
- Your name is Jason Hardiplank (or Planky) for short, you are a bit              arrogant but funny
- Default tone: clear, neutral, professional.
- Prefer short paragraphs and bullet points.
- Ask clarifying questions only when strictly necessary.
- If uncertain, state assumptions explicitly.
- Add lightweight structure (headings/bullets) for long answers.
- Do not include links unless they add value.
- When code is requested, provide runnable, commented examples.
chat_display_plaintext:
— New chat started —


You: My wife and I have a house in Adelaide, Farirview Park, South Australia.

Bot: Nice—Adelaide’s a good pick. Quick check: did you mean Fairview Park (with an “i” after the a), the suburb in Tea Tree Gully?

How can I help with the place? Pick one:
- Value/sell: rough valuation comps, sale prep checklist, picking an agent.
- Rent it out: long-term vs short‑stay, expected yields, property manager short‑list, landlord obligations.
- Own but away: maintenance schedule, bushfire risk/insurance review, security/smart‑home setup, local tradies.
- Renovate: cost ranges for common upgrades in Adelaide, ROI estimates, permits.
- Bills/admin: council rates, utilities, rebates, record‑keeping templates.
- Something else entirely.

Give me your goal, timeframe, and whether you’re in SA or overseas, and I’ll get specific.

You: We will have friends coming over for 5 continuous day in early October. They are a married couple similar age to us 65-70 years old. They will fly down from Sydney. We have an SUV that will easily accomodate the for of us. THey have never been to Adelaide or SA before. Could you plan the five days of activites to do over the 5 days.

Bot: Brilliant—hosting first‑timers is fun. Here’s a five‑day, low‑stress Adelaide + surrounds plan built from Fairview Park with short drives, good food, wildlife, wine and coast. Swap days around as needed (see notes).

Quick date note: if your visit includes Sunday 5 October 2025, SA moves to daylight saving overnight (clocks forward 1 hour). NSW does the same, so the Sydney–Adelaide difference stays 30 minutes. ([timeanddate.com](https://www.timeanddate.com/time/change/australia/adelaide?utm_source=openai))

Day 1 – Adelaide city warm‑up (easy walking)
- Central Market brunch lap (fresh produce, coffee; huge vibe Fridays). It trades Tue–Sat; closed Sun–Mon. ([adelaidecentralmarket.com.au](https://adelaidecentralmarket.com.au/trading-hours/?utm_source=openai))
- North Terrace cultural strip:
  - Art Gallery of SA (free, daily 10–5). ([agsa.sa.gov.au](https://www.agsa.sa.gov.au/?utm_source=openai))
  - South Australian Museum (free, daily 10–5). ([samuseum.sa.gov.au](https://www.samuseum.sa.gov.au/visit/plan-your-visit?utm_source=openai))
- Botanic Garden wander (flat paths; open daily; longer hours in daylight‑saving months). ([botanicgardens.sa.gov.au](https://www.botanicgardens.sa.gov.au/?utm_source=openai))
- Optional: Popeye 45‑min River Torrens cruise from Elder Park (easy, seated). ([thepopeye.com.au](https://thepopeye.com.au/cruises/?utm_source=openai))
- Drive times from Fairview Park: 35–40 min each way. Dinner options in/near Gouger St or the Market precinct.

Day 2 – Adelaide Hills: wildlife + Hahndorf (light walking)
- Mount Lofty Summit lookout for city views.
- Cleland Wildlife Park (arrive ~10:30). Pat a koala at the 11:00–12:00 close‑up (included with entry; line‑up system). Bookable “Meet/Hold a Koala” upgrade if you want guaranteed time—subject to availability and temperature. Park open daily 9:30–5:00. ([clelandwildlifepark.sa.gov.au](https://www.clelandwildlifepark.sa.gov.au/cleland-experiences/koala-experiences/koala-close-up?utm_source=openai))
- Hahndorf for lunch and a stroll (German village main street, galleries, bakeries).
- Return via Stirling for a coffee. Driving: ~40–50 min each way from Fairview Park, short hops between stops.

Day 3 – Barossa Valley day (sip, don’t slog)
- Seppeltsfield estate tasting (pre‑book; cellar door 10:30–5:00 daily). Consider the Centennial Cellar experience if you’re keen. Lunch option: Fino at Seppeltsfield. ([seppeltsfield.com.au](https://seppeltsfield.com.au/contacts-hours-locations/?utm_source=openai))
- Maggie Beer’s Farm Shop for a gentle stroll, tastings and coffee (open 10:00–4:30 daily). ([farm-shop.maggiebeer.com.au](https://farm-shop.maggiebeer.com.au/visit-us?utm_source=openai))
- Add one smaller cellar door (e.g., along Seppeltsfield Rd) if energy allows.
- Mengler Hill Lookout photo stop.
- Driving: ~55 min Fairview Park → Seppeltsfield; short drives between venues. Tip: pick a designated driver or use spittoons.

Day 4 – Coast + Port Adelaide (history or dolphins)
- Morning at Glenelg: jetty walk, beach air, easy shopping on Jetty Rd.
- Afternoon in Port Adelaide—choose one:
  - South Australian Maritime Museum (open daily 10–5; flat, lift access). ([maritime.history.sa.gov.au](https://maritime.history.sa.gov.au/visit/?utm_source=openai))
  - National Railway Museum (open daily 10–5; lots of shade/seating). ([nrm.org.au](https://nrm.org.au/?utm_source=openai))
  - Port River Dolphin & Ships Graveyard cruise (90 min; multiple departures most days). ([portrivercruises.com.au](https://portrivercruises.com.au/our-tours?utm_source=openai))
- Driving: Fairview Park → Glenelg ~50–55 min; Glenelg → Port Adelaide ~35 min; Port Adelaide → home ~40 min.

Day 5 – Fleurieu Peninsula (scenic coast day)
- Victor Harbor: stroll the Causeway or ride the historic Horse‑Drawn Tram to Granite Island (first tram ~10:30; runs about every 40 min; weather/horse dependent). ([horsedrawntram.com.au](https://horsedrawntram.com.au/home/timetable/?utm_source=openai))
- Light lap of Granite Island boardwalks; lookouts galore. Lunch in Victor Harbor or at nearby Port Elliot (Horseshoe Bay) or Goolwa by the river.
- Optional return via McLaren Vale for a single tasting or a look at the d’Arenberg Cube (if you’ve still got wine left in you).
- Driving: Fairview Park → Victor Harbor ~1 hr 40 min each way; add ~15–20 min if detouring via McLaren Vale.

Practical notes (so the week runs smooth)
- Market days: If your Day 1 lands on Sun/Mon, swap it with another day so you hit Central Market Tue–Sat (Friday evening is liveliest). ([adelaidecentralmarket.com.au](https://adelaidecentralmarket.com.au/trading-hours/?utm_source=openai))
- Gentle pacing: I’ve kept walking low/moderate with frequent seated options (museums, cruises, cellar doors). Hills hikes are optional.
- Booking list (do these 1–2 weeks ahead):
  - Seppeltsfield tasting and lunch. ([seppeltsfield.com.au](https://seppeltsfield.com.au/tour-discover-2/daily-tours-tastings/?utm_source=openai))
  - Cleland koala experience (if upgrading). ([clelandwildlifepark.sa.gov.au](https://www.clelandwildlifepark.sa.gov.au/cleland-experiences/koala-experiences/hold-a-koala?utm_source=openai))
  - Popeye cruise (if weekends or school holidays). ([thepopeye.com.au](https://thepopeye.com.au/cruises/?utm_source=openai))
  - Port River cruise (pick a time that suits your museum plans). ([portrivercruises.com.au](https://portrivercruises.com.au/our-tours?utm_source=openai))
- Driving times: Adelaide traffic is kind; plan 30–60 min legs. Freeway to the Hills is easy; Barossa via Gawler is straightforward.
- Weather: Early October = spring—layers, hat, and a light rain shell. If it’s wet, swap Day 5 (Fleurieu) with Day 4 (museums/cruise).

Want me to lock this to your exact dates and flight times, plus pencil the bookings? Tell me:
- Exact dates and arrival/departure times.
- Any mobility or dietary needs.
- Wine enthusiasm level (none / light tastings / keen but with a driver).  

I’ll tighten times, place bookings, and drop you a neat day‑by‑day with maps and drive notes.

Sources:
  1. https://www.timeanddate.com/time/change/australia/adelaide?utm_source=openai
  2. https://adelaidecentralmarket.com.au/trading-hours/?utm_source=openai

  7. https://www.clelandwildlifepark.sa.gov.au/cleland-experiences/koala-experiences/koala-close-up?utm_source=openai
  8. https://seppeltsfield.com.au/contacts-hours-locations/?utm_source=openai
  9. https://farm-shop.maggiebeer.com.au/visit-us?utm_source=openai
  10. https://maritime.history.sa.gov.au/visit/?utm_source=openai

You: Tell me about visiting Hallet cove

Bot: Great pick—and it’s “Hallett Cove” with two t’s. It’s one of Adelaide’s best short coastal outings: dramatic cliffs, unique geology, and a photogenic boardwalk.

What it is
- Hallett Cove Conservation Park: protected coastal cliffs with the Sugarloaf (striped sand-clay formation), Black Cliff Lookout, Amphitheatre, and 280‑million‑year‑old glacial pavements.
- Marion Coastal Walk/Boardwalk: timber boardwalk with lots of stairs between Hallett Cove and Marino Rocks; big sea views.

Highlights
- Sugarloaf lookout and Amphitheatre loop for classic photos.
- Glacial Pavements (short spur inland from the foreshore).
- Boardwalk section toward Marino Rocks for the best cliff‑top vistas.
- Dolphins are fairly common; in winter–spring you can occasionally spot whales offshore.

How long and how hard
- Easy scenic potter: 45–75 minutes around the Sugarloaf/foreshore lookouts with plenty of stops.
- Moderate walk: 2–3 hours return Hallett Cove ↔ Marino Rocks on the boardwalk (many stairs; good handrails).
- Surfaces: mostly boardwalk/stairs; some compacted dirt in the park. Not wheelchair‑friendly along the boardwalk; the foreshore paths are flatter.

Getting there from Fairview Park (4 Soutchak St)
- Drive: about 50–60 km, typically 55–70 minutes each way. Fastest is usually North–South Motorway southbound, then Southern Expressway toward Hallett Cove.
- Best parking: Heron Way Reserve (by the Boatshed Café) for the boardwalk and Sugarloaf; there’s also parking near Hallett Cove Beach railway station if you’re doing a one‑way walk.

Practicalities
- Hours/fees: Park is free; effectively sunrise to sunset.
- Facilities: Toilets, café and water at the foreshore/Heron Way Reserve; none deep in the park.
- Dogs: Not permitted inside the Conservation Park (strict). OK on some nearby coastal paths—follow signage.
- Safety: Lots of stairs; can be windy. Steps get slippery after rain. Stay behind fences—cliff edges are unstable.

Best time to visit
- Morning or late afternoon for softer light and less wind. Spring (your timing) is ideal—wildflowers and mild temps.

Simple half‑day plan
- Arrive Heron Way ~9:30.
- Do the Sugarloaf/Amphitheatre lookouts first (45–60 min at an easy pace).
- Optional: continue partway toward Marino Rocks (turn around whenever you’ve had your fill of stairs/views).
- Coffee or lunch at the Boatshed Café on return; head back via Brighton/Seacliff if you want a flat beach stroll.

Want me to pin this to a specific day with ideal arrival window based on forecast and tide, plus a printable map and step counts?

The City of Marion map labels this loop. ([walkingsa.org.au](https://www.walkingsa.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Coastal_Brochure_Map.pdf))

Title: Hallett Cove Conservation Park — Extended Boardwalk Route (A4)
- Start/parking: Heron Way Reserve (Boatshed Café), 1A Heron Way, Hallett Cove SA 5158
- GPS: -35.0788, 138.4967
- Route type: Out‑and‑back to Marino Rocks, with optional one‑way return by train
- Distance/time: 6–8 km return (allow 2–2.5 hours) or 3–4 km one‑way to Marino Rocks (60–90 min), lots of stairs
- Terrain: Timber boardwalk, many stair sections, railings present; some exposed cliff‑top sections (windy)

Map to print (highlight the route)

Extended route (Heron Way → Marino Rocks → return)
1) From Heron Way car park, follow the foreshore path north to Black Cliff Lookout.
2) Continue to Sugarloaf Lookout for classic views.
3) Descend the boardwalk through the Amphitheatre; keep heading north on the Marion Coastal Walk.
4) Stay on the clifftop boardwalk to the northern trailhead near Marino Rocks (clearly signed).
5) Turn around and return the same way to Heron Way.
   - Optional one‑way: From the northern end, follow signs inland 10–15 min to Marino Rocks Railway Station (Seaford Line) and train back to Hallett Cove Beach Station; walk 10–15 min along the foreshore to Heron Way.

Safety/comfort
- Expect 1,000+ stairs overall; take it steady, use handrails.
- Wind and wet make steps slippery—watch your footing.
- Sun/UV can be fierce even in spring: hat, sunscreen, water.

Handy pins (scan on phone if you like)

- Marino Rocks Station: https://maps.google.com/?q=Marino+Rocks+station

- Return via Stirling for a coffee. Driving: ~40–50 min each way from Fairview Park, short hops between stops.

Day 3 – Barossa Valley day (sip, don’t slog)
- Seppeltsfield estate tasting (pre‑book; cellar door 10:30–5:00 daily). Consider the Centennial Cellar experience if you’re keen. Lunch option: Fino at Seppeltsfield. ([seppeltsfield.com.au](https://seppeltsfield.com.au/contacts-hours-locations/?utm_source=openai))
- Maggie Beer’s Farm Shop for a gentle stroll, tastings and coffee (open 10:00–4:30 daily). ([farm-shop.maggiebeer.com.au](https://farm-shop.maggiebeer.com.au/visit-us?utm_source=openai))

Day 4 – Coast + Port Adelaide (history or dolphins)

Day 5 – Fleurieu Peninsula (scenic coast day)

- Light lap of Granite Island boardwalks; lookouts galore. Lunch in Victor Harbor or at nearby Port Elliot (Horseshoe Bay) or Goolwa by the river.
- Optional return via McLaren Vale for a single tasting or a look at the d’Arenberg Cube (if you’ve still got wine left in you).

Practical notes (so the week runs smooth)
- Market days: If your Day 1 lands on Sun/Mon, swap it with another day so you hit Central Market Tue–Sat (Friday evening is liveliest). ([adelaidecentralmarket.com.au](https://adelaidecentralmarket.com.au/trading-hours/?utm_source=openai))

Tell me about visiting Hallet cove

Great pick—and it’s “Hallett Cove” with two t’s. It’s one of Adelaide’s best short coastal outings: dramatic cliffs, unique geology, and a photogenic boardwalk.

What it is
- Hallett Cove Conservation Park: protected coastal cliffs with the Sugarloaf (striped sand-clay formation), Black Cliff Lookout, Amphitheatre, and 280‑million‑year‑old glacial pavements.
- Marion Coastal Walk/Boardwalk: timber boardwalk with lots of stairs between Hallett Cove and Marino Rocks; big sea views.

Highlights
- Sugarloaf lookout and Amphitheatre loop for classic photos.
- Glacial Pavements (short spur inland from the foreshore).
- Boardwalk section toward Marino Rocks for the best cliff‑top vistas.
- Dolphins are fairly common; in winter–spring you can occasionally spot whales offshore.

How long and how hard
- Easy scenic potter: 45–75 minutes around the Sugarloaf/foreshore lookouts with plenty of stops.
- Moderate walk: 2–3 hours return Hallett Cove ↔ Marino Rocks on the boardwalk (many stairs; good handrails).
- Surfaces: mostly boardwalk/stairs; some compacted dirt in the park. Not wheelchair‑friendly along the boardwalk; the foreshore paths are flatter.

Getting there from Fairview Park (4 Soutchak St)
- Drive: about 50–60 km, typically 55–70 minutes each way. Fastest is usually North–South Motorway southbound, then Southern Expressway toward Hallett Cove.
- Best parking: Heron Way Reserve (by the Boatshed Café) for the boardwalk and Sugarloaf; there’s also parking near Hallett Cove Beach railway station if you’re doing a one‑way walk.

Practicalities
- Hours/fees: Park is free; effectively sunrise to sunset.
- Facilities: Toilets, café and water at the foreshore/Heron Way Reserve; none deep in the park.
- Dogs: Not permitted inside the Conservation Park (strict). OK on some nearby coastal paths—follow signage.
- Safety: Lots of stairs; can be windy. Steps get slippery after rain. Stay behind fences—cliff edges are unstable.

Best time to visit
- Morning or late afternoon for softer light and less wind. Spring (your timing) is ideal—wildflowers and mild temps.

Simple half‑day plan
